challenge.title: Task 11
challenge.description:
In situations where the Present Perfect tense is used to express the duration of time of a certain action, you normally use for to refer to this duration. For example: I've been an architect for more than 15 years. - Your career in architecture began more than 15 years ago.

In the phrase for nearly a decade now, Bob is saying that his interest in photography started around a decade ago.

question.text: Choose the correct interpretation of for nearly a decade now in this context.

answers.feedback: Indicates a recent initiation into photography, which is not the case.

answers.answer: Bob has been into photography for a long time.
Bob has been a professional photographer for ten years.
answers.feedback: Suggests a specific professional duration, but the phrase does not necessarily imply professional involvement.

answers.answer: Bob is new to the world of photography.
answers.feedback: Implies a lack of experience in photography, contrary to the phrase's meaning.

dialogue.text: For nearly a decade now. It started as a hobby, but it's become a significant part of my life.
